data.title: Irving Grant Thalberg Sr (1899-1936)
data.meta_description: Is this your ancestor? Explore genealogy for Irving Thalberg Sr born 1899 Brooklyn, Kings County, New York, United States died 1936 Santa Monica, Los Angeles, California, United States including ancestors + children + 2 photos + more in the free family tree community.
data.text:
Ancestors

Profile last modified 4 Oct 2023 | Created 27 Jun 2015

This page has been accessed 1,442 times.

Irving Thalberg Sr is Notable.

Biography

Irving Grant Thalberg (May 30, 1899 – September 14, 1936) was an American film producer during the early years of motion pictures. He was called "The Boy Wonder" for his youth and ability to select scripts, choose actors, gather production staff, and make profitable films, including Grand Hotel, China Seas, Camille, Mutiny on the Bounty and The Good Earth. [1]

His films carved out an international market, "projecting a seductive image of American life brimming with vitality and rooted in democracy and personal freedom," states biographer Roland Flamini.[2]

Famous in his own right as one of the greatest film producers of all time, Thalberg was also the first husband of Academy Award winning actress, Norma Shearer. He was instrumental in starting with the careers of many, many successful actors and actresses and involved with the production of many, many highly successful films. [3]

Irving was born 30 May 1899 in Brooklyn, New York,[4] the son of William Thalberg and Henrietta Heymann.[5]

He was married to the actress Norman Shearer 29 September 1927 in Beverly Hills, California.[6] They were the parents of Irving Jr. (1930-1987)[7] and Katherine (1935-2006).

Irving died 14 September 1936 in Santa Monica, California. His remains were buried at Forest Lawn Memorial Park in Glendale.[8]

After his premature death from pneumonia at the young age of 37, the motion picture industry created the Irving Thalberg Memorial Award, to reward excellence in producers in the movie business.[9]

Obituary:[10]

Irving G. Thalberg Dies in Hollywood

Hollywood, Sept.14--Irving Grant Thalberg,motion picture production genius and husband of Norma Shearer, film star, died at 10:16 a.m. today after a brief illness which resulted in lobular pneumonia.

Thalberg, a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer vice-president, was 37, and rated as one of the industry's outstanding executives. With his passing, death struck at the very heart of Hollywood. In all of its amazing history the motion picture industry has had no man who made his life so much a part of it. He was the "little Napoleon of the films. Almost as a boy he had directed the destiny of pictures.

The end came at his home in Santa Monica. At his bedside were his wife, Norma Shearer, Mr. and Mrs. William Thalsberg, his father and mother, Mrs. Edith Shearer, mother of Norma Shearer, Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Welngarten (his sister), and Mr. and Mrs. Berale Hyman.
